A debt default was never a viable option.

Yet the GOP was willing to crash the economy if we did not give into their extreme ransom note. 

Tonight, I reluctantly voted to pass the budget proposal to prevent a catastrophic default. http://pbs.twimg.com/ext_tw_video_thumb/1664108287434915843/pu/img/M5p9rpeo4eEF8LGo.jpg https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1664108287434915843/pu/vid/480x270/tPBU0u_D-mH0SAom.mp4?tag=12

This agreement represents a compromise, which means there are provisions that I do not support; however, this bill is far better for our country & my constituents than the default we would face if it failed.

For weeks, I called on Republicans to prioritize the needs of the American people over their own party‚Äôs interests & cleanly raise the debt ceiling. 

Unfortunately, too many were willing to default without some compromise on spending, despite how catastrophic a default would be.

The Bipartisan Budget Agreement protects Social Security, Medicaid, Medicare, veterans benefits, & investments in the clean energy & transportation economy.  

While the GOP held our economy hostage, congressional Democrats & @POTUS fought to put people over politics.

I reluctantly voted yes on the Bipartisan Budget Agreement. This bill averts a catastrophic default that would have triggered a recession, cost millions of jobs, devastated retirement accounts, & disrupted federal benefits for countless Americans. üßµ https://mcclellan.house.gov/media/press-releases/mcclellan-votes-support-bipartisan-budget-agreement

This is a difficult decision to make, but this is the responsibility every member takes on when they‚Äôre elected to Congress. We all answer to our voters and I look forward to having a dialog about my vote. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fxc5ZaqaQAE70Vq.jpg

Southwest Ohio sent me to Congress in part to restore normalcy in government; to be bipartisan, accountable, transparent, and reliable.

That‚Äôs who I am, and that‚Äôs why I voted yes.

We need more bipartisan, pragmatic leaders.

There were folks on the left and right that voted against this bill. Had they prevailed, we could have defaulted on America and sent the economy into a tailspin.

America needs more folks who are committed to getting things done.
This¬†bipartisan¬†bill would do that, so I voted yes. We were able to avoid a catastrophic default, and get a budget done that protected folks back home.

What I needed to see from this bill was that Southwest Ohioans would be protected: that no veterans would lose benefits, folks would continue to receive Social Security checks, and that no child would lose access to food through the SNAP program.

The bill represents the realities of a divided Congress.

President Biden and congressional leaders were¬†always¬†going to have to¬†negotiate on a budget. I had urged folks to do this months ago.
The jobs, savings, and lives of Americans should not be bargaining chips. It‚Äôs not fair to¬†the people we serve.

Washington cannot normalize this¬†process.

Brinkmanship on the question of defaulting in America is¬†reckless.

Folks were calling us panicked about their Social Security checks, worried they might lose their healthcare, or whether or not the economy would crash.

I‚Äôm committed to being a new type of national leader: transparent, accountable, bipartisan, and reliable.

I want to share my takeaways from this vote - and an explanation for why I voted yes.

Tonight marked¬†the¬†most important vote¬†I‚Äôve taken as a member of Congress.

I voted¬†with a bipartisan majority of my colleagues to¬†avoid¬†a catastrophic¬†default¬†and a budget that protects Social Security and Medicare.

I strongly encourage my colleagues on both sides to back the #BipartisanBudgetAct.

Washington cannot normalize this chaos. Folks reached out anxious about their Social Security, healthcare, and the economy.

America needs more bipartisan, pragmatic leaders.

We CANNOT default. http://pbs.twimg.com/ext_tw_video_thumb/1664058280858066946/pu/img/q8ofTtkI4XMW8c4Z.jpg https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1664058280858066946/pu/vid/480x270/TvYUPDZ2pPXRlzzd.mp4?tag=12

‚ÄúMarxists get up early in the Morning to further their cause.¬† We must get up earlier to defend our freedom.‚Äù - Margaret Thatcher

Our Republic was not built on compromise, it was built on the fighting spirit of patriots willing to make the ultimate sacrifice. Now we can‚Äôt find enough patriots to vote NO on a debt ceiling bill that threatens the fabric of our nation.

God gave Adam a job in the Garden of Eden.¬†Work has been a good thing since the beginning of time, but Joe Biden is stripping people of the dignity it provides by removing work requirements from welfare.

In January, twenty of us stood firm in defense of Liberty.¬† The debt ceiling bill defies the terms of the agreement we fought so hard to achieve, but this time it will take more than ‚ÄúThe Twenty‚Äù to make history.

Margaret Thatcher declared, ‚ÄúI came to office with one deliberate intent: to change Britain from a dependent to a self-reliant society ‚Äì from a give-it-to-me, to a do-it-yourself nation.‚Äù¬†I will vote NO on a debt ceiling bill that discourages the dignity of work.
Margaret Thatcher worked to ‚Äúroll back the frontiers of the state‚Äù by incentivizing work not handouts.
Our generation inherited a Republic that was solvent.¬†We are squandering that inheritance.¬†If we continue, the next generation will be saddled with our debt.¬†That is morally wrong.
I was elected to help eliminate the existential threat that our debt poses. This debt ceiling bill is a short-term fix to a long-term problem and I will vote NO to kicking the can down the road.

If the debt ceiling bill was so great, there would be no need to deploy pundits to try justifying it. They are trying to defend the indefensible.¬† I will be voting NO to more debt, NO to more government handouts and NO to expanding the IRS.

I will continue to engage in good-faith discussions about spending and responsible management of our country‚Äôs debt. 

What I cannot do is support draconian cuts that hurt seniors, children, low-income families, and the environment.

The debt ceiling is about paying our existing bills‚Äî debts that accrued under both Democratic and Republican presidents. It is abhorrent that Republicans would jeopardize the full faith and credit of the United States to push through policies that hurt everyday Americans.

Many of the provisions included in the deal are legislative changes Republicans could not get through the regular legislative process. 

We cannot normalize the hostage-taking of the debt ceiling as a negotiation tactic.

Instead of voting for a clean debt ceiling bill, which they did multiple times during the Trump Administration, the House GOP has brought us to the brink of default -- something that has never occurred in U.S. history.
And all of the budget cuts are made from programs other than defense, for which spending is actually increased.
It restarts payments on student loans without putting a safety net in place for vulnerable borrowers.
safety net programs like SNAP are designed to help. The bill also makes changes to environmental laws that would set us back on protecting clean air and water and transitioning to clean energy.

Although I am grateful that the deal doesn‚Äôt include some of the House GOP‚Äôs most egregious demands‚Äîsuch as gutting Medicaid & repealing clean energy tax credits‚Äîthe budget cuts & burdensome work requirements will harm the people...

It would be devastating for our country to default, but I could not in good conscience vote for a plan to lift the debt ceiling that would harm some of the most vulnerable people in our country and undermine bedrock environmental laws.
